headline.main: THE WAR IN THE BORDER STATES.; Encouraging but Not Decisive Successes in Kentucky Gen. Sherman to Command Wants of the Department, & c.

docs.lead_paragraph: Our successes at "Wild Cat," Burkesville, West Liberty, Prestonburgh, Woodbury and Morgantown are encouraging, but they are by no means decisive. Our military lines are everywhere advancing, yet we may meet with future backsets and reverses in Kentucky, Missouri and Virginia.

docs.snippet: Gen. SCOTT took his departure for Europe yesterday afternoon in the steamer Arago, of tire Southampton and Havre line. He was accompanied by his son-in-law, Col. SCOTT, and family. The arrangements for his journey had been all completed on Friday,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Gen. SCOTT took his departure for Europe yesterday afternoon in the steamer Arago, of tire Southampton and Havre line. He was accompanied by his son-in-law, Col. SCOTT, and family. The arrangements for his journey had been all completed on Friday, and at 9 o'clock yesterday morning the General left the Brevoort House for the steamer in a carriage with his daughter, Mrs. GOULD HOYT, and Hon. GOUVENEUE KEMBLE.

docs.snippet: Gen. McCLELLAN heartily approves the proposition for an exchange of prisoners. This has been his sentiment from the start and I believe the majority of the Cabinet have always taken the same side. Gen. McCLELLAN'S views are sustained by his...
docs.lead_paragraph: Gen. McCLELLAN heartily approves the proposition for an exchange of prisoners. This has been his sentiment from the start and I believe the majority of the Cabinet have always taken the same side. Gen. McCLELLAN'S views are sustained by his confidential friend, the distinguished Ex-Attorney-General, EDWIN ...

headline.main: THE TROOPS IN WESTERN VIRGINIA.; INTERESTING STATEMENT FROM GEN. ROSECRANS. THE GREAT REBELLION.

docs.lead_paragraph: SIR: The sympathies of the people of Ohio and Indiana have been deeply excited by accounts of the destitution and suffering of our troops in this Department. Moved by these sympathies, they have been making laudable exertions to procure the means of supplying our wants and alleviating our distress.

docs.snippet: Mrs. WINSLOW, an experienced nurse and female physician, has a Soothing Syrup for children teething, which greatly facilitates the process of teething, by softening the gums, reducing all inflammation will allay all pain, and is sure to regulate the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Mrs. WINSLOW, an experienced nurse and female physician, has a Soothing Syrup for children teething, which greatly facilitates the process of teething, by softening the gums, reducing all inflammation will allay all pain, and is sure to regulate the bowels. Depend upon it, mothers, it will give rest to yourselves and relief and health to your infants. Perfectly safe in all cases.

docs.snippet: The Committee appointed by the Chamber of Commerce to present their resolutions of respect to Gen. SCOTT met yesterday at 9  o'clock, at the Brevoort House, and paid their respects to the General.

headline.main: RESPECT TO GEN. SCOTT.; Complimentary Visits from a Committee of the Chamber of Commerce, and from the Union Defence Committee.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Committee appointed by the Chamber of Commerce to present their resolutions of respect to Gen. SCOTT met yesterday at 9 o'clock, at the Brevoort House, and paid their respects to the General.

headline.main: THE GREAT REBELLION.; Continuance of the Fighting in Western Virginia. A Decisive Movement About to be Made by the National Forces. Gen. Rosecrans Reinforced with Artillery. HIGHLY IMPORTANT FROM KENTUCKY. An Expedition from Cairo Against Columbus. A Warm Action Going on at Last Accounts. IMPORTANT NEWS FROM MISSOURI. A Better Feeling in the National Army. The Chances for a Great Battle More Remote. Rebel Report of the Capture of the Privateer Sumter.SPECIAL DISPATCH FROM WASHINGTON. CHEERING NEWS FROM EUROPE. THE REBELS ON THE UPPER POTOMAC. AFFAIRS DOWN THE POTOMAC. THE BATTERIES ON THE POTOMAC. ANXIETY IN REFERENCE TO THE FLEET. NO INFORMATION FROM GEN. ROSENCRANS. THE BLOCKADE AT CHARLESTON. THE ESCAPE OF THE SUMTER. THE CIVIL CASES IN ALEXANDRIA. CIVIL OFFICERS TO BE DEPOSED. JOHN A. WASHINGTON'S ESTATE. ACCOUNTS OF THE LIVERPOOL CONSULATE. THE NEW MINISTER FROM SWEDEN. THE RETIREMENT OF GEN. SCOTT. GEN. MITCHELL IN WASHINGTON. SEPARATION OF FAMILIES. MINISTER TO JAPAN. AN APPOINTMENT. RETURN OF SECRETARY SEWARD. THE SANITARY
